awd_titl_txt: A Systematic Large-Scale Survey of the Overlooked Population of Small Objects Between the Orbits of the Outer Planets.
awd_abstract_narration:
Centaurs are small bodies residing on unstable orbits between Jupiter and Neptune. They have been scattered out of their original orbits far from the Sun and offer an opportunity to learn about the nature of the more distant objects to which they are related. Understanding these objects will give astronomers an opportunity to constrain models of Solar System formation. The PI and her team will use data from the Pan-STARRS catalog to find more small Centaurs as well as using large telescopes to study these objects. They will look for signs that these Centaurs show some sort of comet-like activity, and they will use numerical models to explain this activity. The PI will work with professional education staff at the Planetary Science Institute to develop and deliver 3-day workshops to teachers of grades 3-8 in southern Arizona. 

The team will conduct a systematic Centaur population study utilizing data from a single, well-characterized all-sky survey, Pan-STARRS1, that will allow them to shed light on the evolution of Centaurs from the Scattered Disk to Jupiter Family Comets by calculating their debiased size-frequency distribution (SFD), and to better understand the effects of dynamical history of Centaurs on their activity. They will: 1) Search for new Centaurs in the Pan-STARRS1 detection catalog to obtain targets of opportunity, and to collect a statistically adequate sample for calculating a debiased size-frequency distribution; 2) model the Pan-STARRS1 survey biases with a synthetic Centaur model and apply the resulting detection efficiency to the real data in order to calculate a debiased SFD down to kilometer-size regime; 3) make deep-imaging observations of Centaurs with a wide range of perihelion distances to search for and to characterize their activity using photometric analysis and numerical dust modeling; and 4) run dynamical integrations and utilize thermal modeling to investigate correlations of Centaur activity with their orbital history, with implications for the activity triggers and composition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Apart from the Sun and the planets Solar system contains numerous much smaller objects – dust grains, rock-like asteroids and icy comets that develop gaseous tails when their pass the part of their orbits nearest to the Sun.  There is also a group of small bodies that doesn’t exactly fit in any of the categories. Centaurs, which orbit between Jupiter and Neptune, are a transient population being slowly scattered and replenished from the trans-Neptunian populations of icy objects preserved in current state since the Solar system’s formation.  The Centaur population provides an extremely useful clues to the properties of small trans-Neptunian objects which are beyond our observational limit. In addition, Centaurs are also mysterious objects that look like asteroids but sometimes act like comets and develop a tail, to which their own their name after the mythical half-human, half-horse. This project combined observational and computer modelling approaches to map the occurrence of comet-like, active Centaurs and to understand what triggers the cometary behavior only in the small part of the population, while the remainder remains quiescent.

We have utilized the twin 8-meter Gemini telescopes located in Hawaii and in Chile with the capability to cover both the southern and the northern sky to survey almost 100 Centaurs (about half of the entire known population) over four years in order to find signs of activity. We have systematically surveyed Centaurs spanning a wide range of sizes and orbits, with an initial focus on objects approaching their perihelion passage, because approaching the minimal orbital distance from the Sun maximizes the surface temperatures and thus also chances the ices contained in the Centaur nucleus will start sublimating and create a cometary tail. We have also used a computer model – numerical integrator, capable of tracking orbital evolution of Centaurs centuries into the past to understand how the chaotic gravitational influence from giant planets can shift the orbits of these small bodies over time. We have paired the dynamical model with a thermal computer model that was able to translate the orbital evolution into the changes of thermal environment inside the Centaur nucleus and follow the phase transition of ices present depending on its size and physical structure.

We have shown that unlike the common asteroid-like Centaurs, all known active Centaurs have experienced a close encounter with Jupiter or Saturn leading to a rapid reshaping of their orbits from elliptical to more circular in a matter of mere months. We have named this orbital shifts the ‘a-jump’ because the reshaping is done by a sudden decrease in semi-major axis ‘a’ and eccentricity and it is consistent with an activity-triggering event in Centaurs. Our thermal simulations confirm a-jumps could induce thermal waves capable of reaching previously intact ice deposits in the Centaur interiors and jump start multiple gas producing events, such as

sublimation of supervolatiles ices. Centaurs could undergo several orbit-changing a-jumps during their lifetime, which could lead to depletion of their ice supply and eventual dormancy. Such object than becomes indistinguishable from an ordinary asteroid. Our simulations thus help to solve the long-standing mystery why only a handful of Centaurs are active – these are dynamically young objects with fresh ice reservoirs that had been just recently pushed towards warmer parts of the Solar system by an a-jump. On the other hand, the majority of quiescent Centaurs are either orbiting in the outskirts of the region, where the temperatures are too low for the ice sublimation to occur, or they have been already thoroughly thermally processed and enter a period of dormancy. To date this project has produced 2 peer-reviewed papers with further publications in development.  

In addition, our team has prepared a public outreach project in the form of a series of ACCESS (Asteroids, Centaurs and Comets: Exploring the Solar System) workshops for teachers based on the highly successful PSI’s workshop program covering elementary- to high-school level. The teachers were involved in solar system body classification activities developed specifically for these workshops. On top of the workshops our team also sent copies of the Classification Activity to 27 former Astronomy Camp leaders covering 21 councils in 18 states. The activities will potentially reach girl scout troops (10-30 girls in each troop), astronomy clubs and library programs.
